title.rendered: Austin Air Quality: What Can You to Do to Improve Your Home’s Air Quality?

content.rendered:
Like most people, you may also associate pollution with outdoor areas only. But the truth is, the most dangerous contaminants lurk inside your home. Dust, animal feces, dead animal’s body parts, and household cleaners are just a few pollutants that make your indoor air quality unhealthy.

And considering the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, it’s safe to assume that you and your family are spending the majority of your time indoors. So, if you’re looking to improve the Austin air quality in your home, look no further. Here are the most effective ways you can clarify the indoor air and breathe easier.

Buy Indoor-Friendly Houseplants

Why not improve the Austin air quality the same way that Mother Nature does? Buy some succulents and plants and place them around your home, especially in your bedroom and living room. Plants such as peace lily, chrysanthemums, Boston fern, rubber plants, English ivy, and aloe vera actively remove toxins from the air.

Clean the Filters In Your HVAC System

The filter in your air conditioner or furnace is the first line of defense against indoor pollution. These filters trap mold, viruses, and bacteria, and prevent them from entering your home via ductwork. This is why it’s crucial to change these filters on a regular basis. A filter that’s clogged up with dirt, dust, and other tiny debris cannot purify your indoor air. Consider calling an HVAC expert to check the Austin air quality in your home if it’s been a while since your last HVAC maintenance.

Get Air Circulation Going

Unless it’s extremely cold or hot outside, you must open your doors and windows every day. This allows the dusty and stale air to escape the house and lets the fresh, clean air enter indoors. If you don’t have an exhaust fan in your basement, attic, or other closed-up spaces, consider getting one installed. 

Keep An Eye On Humidity Levels 

Mold and dust mites thrive in moist environments, so make sure you maintain ideal humidity levels in your home. This is usually between 30 and 50%. We recommend getting a humidifier that can reduce the amount of moisture in your home’s air. In addition, a humidifier also prevents mold and other allergens from taking root indoors. If you already have a humidifier, make sure you empty out the drip pans on a regular basis.

Stop Smoking!

If you’ve heard it once, you’ve heard it a thousand times. But seriously, cigarette smoke can wreak havoc on your indoor air quality. Breathing in air that’s been contaminated with cigarette smoke can increase the risk of asthma, heart problems, respiratory ailments, and even cancer. It’s time to make your home a non-smoking space. If you smoke, and you have other people living in your home, especially little children, think about the risks you’re exposing them to.

Clean Austin Air Quality Indoors Doesn’t Have To Be Expensive

Breathing in clean, fresh air is your right. You don’t need to invest in expensive air purification systems to improve the air quality in your home. Just follow the tips shared above and you’ll be fine.

However, if you’ve tried these suggestions and you still have indoor air quality issues, it’s time to call an Austin air quality expert. At United Home Services, we offer a variety of HVAC services, such as duct cleaning, chimney cleaning, and AC filter replacement to address your indoor air quality. Call us today at 866-847-7454 or complete this online contact form to know how we can help you.
